awd_titl_txt: Timing and Spatial Distribution of Antarctic Ice Sheet Growth and Sea-ice Formation across the Eocene-Oligocene Transition
awd_abstract_narration:
Abstract (non-technical)
Sea level rise is a problem of global importance and it is increasingly affecting the tens of millions of Americans living along coastlines. The melting of glaciers in mountain areas worldwide in response to global warming is a major cause of sea level rise and increases in nuisance coastal flooding. However, the world's largest land-based ice sheets are situated in the Polar Regions and their response under continued warming is very difficult to predict. One reason for this uncertainty is a lack of observations of ice behavior and melt under conditions of warming, as it is a relatively new global climate state lasting only a few generations so far. Researchers will investigate ice growth on Antarctica under past warm conditions using geological archives embedded in the layers of sand and mud under the sea floor near Antarctica. By peeling back at the layers beneath the seafloor investigators can read the history book of past events affecting the ice sheet. The Antarctic continent on the South Pole, carries the largest ice mass in the world. The investigator's findings will substantially improve scientists understanding of the response of ice sheets to global warming and its effect on sea level rise.


Abstract (technical)
The melt of land based ice is raising global sea levels with at present only minor contributions from polar ice sheets. However, the future role of polar ice sheets in climate change is one of the most critical uncertainties in predictions of sea level rise around the globe. The respective roles of oceanic and atmospheric greenhouse forcing on ice sheets are poorly addressed with recent measurements of polar climatology, because of the extreme rise in greenhouse forcing the earth is experiencing at this time. Data on the evolution of the West Antarctic ice sheet is particularly sparse. To address the data gap, researchers will reconstruct the timing and spatial distribution of Antarctic ice growth through the last greenhouse to icehouse climate transition around 37 to 33 Ma. They will collect sedimentological and geochemical data on core samples from a high-latitude paleoarchive to trace the shutdown of the chemical weathering system, the onset of glacial erosion, ice rafting, and sea ice development, as East and West Antarctic ice sheets coalesced in the Weddell Sea sector. Their findings will lead to profound increases in the understanding of the role of greenhouse forcing in ice sheet development and its effect on the global climate system.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Earth's climate transitions are strongly coupled to the behavior of ice sheets. Ice sheet melt causes sea level rise and impacts key oceanic processes, such as ocean heat transport, nutrient availability and carbon sequestration. Analyses of the cascading effects of marine ice-sheet growth and mass loss in past warm periods inform scientists' understanding of the mechanics of climate change projected under future warming.

This project funded by the National Science Foundation targeted the onset of Antarctic glaciation in the Weddell Sea, Antarctica, using an existing geological archive of drill core material collected by the Ocean Drilling Program. The Weddell Sea is a key area in the global ocean circulation system to the south of the Atlantic Ocean. In the Weddell Sea, warmer Atlantic water masses mix with cold water masses that have come into contact with the floating ice margins. Warm incoming water masses melt ice sheets from below, a process that extracts heat from the ocean. The cold water is fed back into the global ocean conveyer through the production of Antarctic Bottom Water that takes up carbon from the atmosphere and stores it in the deep ocean.

Analytical work on samples from ODP Site 696 was carried out at Montclair State University and consisted of instrument analyses of the chemistry and grain-size of the ocean mud that accumulated on the seafloor over time. The microscale texture of the sand was analyzed with an electron microscope and shows evidence of transport by icebergs from glacial sources in East and West Antarctica. This data collected on layers of mud and sand stacked up in this geological archive of climate change history, show the connection between changes in the ice sheet and the ocean environment. The project focuses on the Eocene warm period around 34 million years ago and contrasts findings with data from the Oligocene cooling to understand the interactions between the ice a sheet and the ocean across a range of climate states. The Eocene warm period is used here as an example of climate warming that occurs under extremely high levels of greenhouse gases in the atmosphere.

The project results demonstrate that the presence or absence of a large ice sheet impacts the intensity of polar ocean circulation in the Weddell Sea, which appears to be faster in the warm period without ice and slows down as an ice sheet expands to the coast and produces icebergs. The data also show that the marine-based West Antarctic Ice Sheet established itself in a temporary colder climate state that developed after the growth of the larger East Antarctic Ice Sheet. Furthermore, climate change and changes in the ice sheet were associated with a temporary lack of oxygen at the seafloor and dissolution of carbon, strongly impacting the high latitude ocean environment. Because of the key role of the Weddell Sea as an area of deepwater formation that feeds into the global ocean conveyer, these environmental changes likely had far-reaching effects.

The project contributed to the operation and management of laboratory facilities and provided basic research opportunities for students at Montclair State University, a Minority Serving Doctoral Research University. An undergraduate student gained work experience and was exposed to research through employment as a laboratory technician on this project. Furthermore, the thesis and dissertation work of two graduate students was directly funded by this project. Public talks, panels and other outreach events were held in person and online (during the pandemic) in collaboration with a public library, a large local retirement community, environmental student clubs, a church with a community college, and a 4-year college. The results of this project are of high societal relevance in the light of the current increasing ocean heat and the ocean's high heat capacity. Training the next generation of scientists and transferring this knowledge to the public are important broader impacts of this work.
